Subjective: Sore throat x 3 days. Severe, unbearable pain on swallowing. Subjective fever this morning. Preceded by cough last week, now resolved. Used paracetamol and ibuprofen with poor relief. No current cough, shortness of breath, or runny nose. Able to drink despite pain. No known sick contacts. Past hx of sore throat, treated with antibiotics once in childhood. Concern: Worried about peritonsillar abscess (friend had one). Request: Wants antibiotics for faster recovery.
Objective: Vitals: T 38.3 C, SpO2 98%. Ears: Left ear normal. Right ear mild external canal erythema, TM normal. Neck: Small, non-pathological submandibular lymph nodes. Throat: Pharyngeal arch slightly red. Tonsils bilaterally enlarged with some slough, not kissing. Uvula median. No signs of abscess. Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Assessment: Acute pharyngitis, likely viral etiology. No evidence of peritonsillar abscess.
Plan:
- Explained likely viral cause; antibiotics not indicated and offer minimal benefit (~0.5 day shorter duration).
- Reassured no signs of abscess.
- Pain management: Paracetamol up to 4x/day. May add Ibuprofen 400mg up to 3x/day.
- Advice: Maintain hydration. Cold drinks or popsicles may soothe pain.
- Safety Netting: Return if symptoms worsen, develops shortness of breath, or unable to swallow.
